Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Developing Course Modules to Teach Service-Oriented Programming through Exemplification and Visualization

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Service oriented programming (SOP) is a programming technique to build software applications using services provided on the web as the building blocks. With cloud computing and mobile devices becoming ubiquitous, SOP is becoming even more crucial, but has not made significant inroads into the U.S. undergraduate computing curricula. This project represents a well-conceived effort to address this shortcoming by developing coursework in SOP to ensure that U.S. students are prepared in this crucial technology, thus competitive in the global software development marketplace.

This project is being jointly conducted at three diverse participating institutions: Howard University in Washington, DC, the State University of New York at Oswego, and the Rochester Institute of Technology in Rochester, NY. Three reusable curricular modules in SOP are being designed for different undergraduate computing courses - a first year introductory programming course, a sophomore course, and a senior-level course. These curricular materials are being constructed on a carefully crafted platform that provides examples and visualization to help achieve effective learning. A modular approach is being used to ensure that the developed curricular materials will be useful for a variety of undergraduate institutions across the United States. Project results are being broadly disseminated through various channels, including regional and national workshops, institutional websites and the National STEM Distributed Learning Resource Center.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Americans have made the world wide web part of their daily lives, and utilize the software services provided on the web for critical day-to-day activities such as financial transactions, communication and even healthcare. It is crucial that these web services be constructed reliably, securely and rapidly. To achieve this vision, programmers need to use existing web services directly, and also use them to create new web services. Unfortunately, this approach, called service-oriented programming (SOP), is not taught in nearly all undergraduate computer science and software engineering degree programs in the US.

 

To address the stated shortfall, this project used a two-prong approach. First, using pedagogically sound design, the project created a set of three course modules that could be taught flexibly to undergraduates in three institutions: Rochester Institute of Technology, the State University of New York College at Oswego, and Howard University. The SOP modules were taught multiple times at the three institutions, being revised constantly based on student and faculty feedback. Students taking these SOP course modules not only learned current research and practice in SOP and web services, but they also gained the confidence in working these concepts. Second, as teaching students only at these three institutions is insufficient, the project also focused on increasing the number of faculty willing and qualified to teach SOP to undergraduate students, including those from populations underrepresented in the STEM disciplines of computer science and software engineering.

 

There were several broader impacts of the project. Hands-on workshops for faculty from other institutions were organized at different locations including the investigators’ host institutions:

Rochester Institute of Technology in Rochester, NY (2013) and Howard University in Washington, DC (2014). In addition, workshops for faculty were held at international conferences for computing academics held in Oklahoma City (2013) and Atlanta (2014). The project was also selected for presentation at the NSF Showcase held in Atlanta (2014), the Envisioning the Future of Undergraduate STEM Education (EnFUSE): Research and Practice Symposium in Washington DC (2016), and the American Association of Engineering Education (ASEE) Annual Conference in New Orleans (2016). Other accomplishments include the publishing of scholarly papers at international conferences in computing and engineering education, the training of faculty from Minority-Serving Institutions such as Howard and Lincoln, the improved education of graduate students due to theses/capstone projects, and the direct impact on American undergraduate students who learned the course materials developed by the funded project.
